prompt.p: A young patient presents with polyuria and excessive thirst for water. She is producing large amounts of very dilute urine with a low specific gravity (no ketones or glucose). A water deprivation test does not reduce the urine output, nor does it respond to desmopressin.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

modalFeedback.p: Option C is Correct. See Targeted Learning for further information.
Option A is Incorrect. This is due to the failure of the pituitary to produce antidiuretic hormone (ADH). Therefore giving desmopressin (synthetic ADH) would reduce urine volume.
Option B is Incorrect. Urine dipstick is normal.
Option D is Incorrect. Patients with psychogenic polydipsia typically have a normal physiological response to water deprivation. Urine volume is reduced and urine is more concentrated.

Option E is Incorrect. This can cause syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) which causes hyponatremia. SIADH would not cause polyuria, and a water deprivation test would not improve this symptom.
